tweet_text: While I remain concerned about the overall size of our defense budget, there is much to support in this year‚Äôs NDAA. I look forward to Congress's continued work to support servicemembers and military families in San Antonio and across the country. (13/13)

name: Joaquin Castro

7‚É£ Improving National Security Research
 
My final provision in the NDAA requires ODNI to submit a report to Congress on how the Intelligence Community can translate open-source materials and publish them for policymakers, academics, journalists, and others. (12/13)

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
6‚É£ Improving Diversity Within the Intelligence Community
 
My language in the NDAA would require @ODNIGov to submit a report to Congress that documents barriers to promotion for women and minorities and proposals to overcome those barriers. (11/13)

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
5‚É£ Expediting Declassification of CIA Records (w/@RepGallagher)

The government has an obligation to be transparent and accountable. This NDAA language will expedite CIA declassification by requiring the CIA Historical Review Panel to report directly to the CIA Director. (10/13)

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
3‚É£ Expanding U.S. Leadership in International Organizations By:
üëâCreating new authorities to place qualified Americans at UN agencies.
üëâAuthorizing @StateDept to give housing allowances to more staff at the @USUN so the mission can be fully staffed. (9/13)

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
2‚É£ Higher Pay for Military & Foreign Service Spouses
 
When military & foreign service families are sent overseas, spouses employed by the federal government can often continue their jobs through telework. My NDAA language would make sure they're paid fairly while abroad. (8/13)

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: Thank you to @CarlosAngeles25, @payourinterns and all those who have pushed for years to expand paid internship opportunities inside and outside the federal government. (7/13)

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
1‚É£ Increasing Paid Internships at @StateDept
 
Unpaid internships make it harder for underrepresented groups to bring their talents to public service. The language I wrote in the NDAA requires State to shift to üíØ paid internships & help interns cover travel + housing. (6/13)

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Read the full @USGAO report on Latino underrepresentation in American media: https://t.co/tFIJUBiE0B

Read highlights of the report in Spanish: https://t.co/zoOcDjDeFr

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: RT @cgrisales: Interesting thread on Latinos and media representation following new GAO report from Rep. @JoaquinCastrotx

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
We need the media industry to understand that this is a foundational issue for Latinos and for the country at large.

Their decisions about which stories to tell, which actors to cast, and which authors to publish will shape the future for Latinos in America.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Fourth, I‚Äôve nominated or supported the nomination of Latinos to federal boards and commissions & pushed for Latino inclusion in the National Film Registry.

Lastly, I work with a coalition of advocates to cast a spotlight on Latino underrepresentation in media and entertainment.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Third, I‚Äôve put forward legislation to use the influence of the federal government to drive change.

I recently got an amendment into the National Apprenticeship Act that would open up Department of Labor support to the media & entertainment industries for paid apprenticeships.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
First, I‚Äôve engaged directly with more than a dozen major media companies across various platforms to seek accountability on these issues.

Second, I've worked w/members of Congress & state legislators to apply greater scrutiny to public subsidies that benefit media companies.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: Federal regulators play an important role in enforcing equal opportunity, but I also want to touch briefly on some of the other work I‚Äôve done ‚Äî in collaboration with many advocates ‚Äî to open more doors for Latinos in media.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
This week, my office is sending a letter to the FCC and the EEOC that asks them to move swiftly to execute the GAO's recommendations, which I hope they will do.

I will also continue to urge regulators to carefully consider how proposed media mergers can impact Latinos.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: In federal agency responses to the GAO‚Äôs recommendations, both the EEOC and the FCC acknowledged the value of data-sharing between the two agencies and committed to exploring opportunities to do that.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Labor unions also play an important gatekeeping role in media & the EEOC requires certain unions to file a report on the demographics of their members.

But its list isn‚Äôt complete, and it needs the help of local unions to build a full picture of who should submit these reports.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: @FCC If the @USEEOC (the main regulator overseeing equal opportunity) shared the info it has w/the FCC, we would have a more complete picture of if media companies are following federal anti-discrimination statutes. The FCC could use that info when deciding to renew station licensing.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Federal regulators have many tools to ensure workforce diversity, but gaps in data sharing & reporting make it harder to root out discrimination.

For example, the @FCC relies on companies to self-report discrimination complaints, often resulting in an incomplete picture.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
The new GAO report on Latino representation in American media looked at the way that government regulators currently enforce equal opportunity and found several gaps that can be fixed without new legislation or major regulatory overhauls.

Here is what the GAO recommends ‚¨áÔ∏è

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
But in my discussions with media leaders, I've become increasingly convinced that the industry is not going to be able to solve this problem on its own.

Existing patterns will continue until the federal government sets standards for how media companies should conduct themselves.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Now, we must give credit where it is due.

GAO's report outlines several steps that major media companies have taken to increase diversity, including tying executive compensation to diversity goals & prioritizing succession planning to include leaders from diverse backgrounds.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: RT @WeAreUnidosUS: .@JoaquinCastrotx's new @USGAO report is a call to action to achieve greater Latino representation in the media industry‚Ä¶

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
3. The dearth of Latino representation among talent agents, media executives, and other decision-makers has meant a lack of imagination about the stories we can tell. 

From romance to horror stories to non-fiction and more, Latinos authors have a lot to offer.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: 2. Latinos face challenges accessing professional networks in the US media industry, including unions, which can require a baseline level of experience as a condition of membership.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
1. Financial Barriers

The burden of unpaid internships & junior positions makes it hard to earn a living wage. And at senior levels, compensation models such as royalties pay out small sums over years, therefore people of modest means have difficulty staying in the industry.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Now, the fundamental question is: What do we do about this and how does the federal government play a role?

GAO researchers conducted a series of interviews with stakeholders from across the media industry and they identified a range of issues. I want to touch on a few...

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: The problem is especially acute for Latina women, who make up just three percent of workers in the media industry when service jobs are excluded.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Over the last several decades, most major corporations have made commitments to improving workforce diversity, and I believe that many of those commitments are sincere.

But over the last decade, the levels of Latino employment in American media have barely budged.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
After the release of last year‚Äôs report, @USGAO went back to work to produce a broader analysis of the factors contributing to Latino underrepresentation in media and to assess the role of the federal government in addressing this systemic problem.

What they found was shocking.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
In March, the newly formed @wbd announced a 13-member Board of Directors without a single Latino, and execs proceeded with a slew of cancellations that snuffed out the potential of Latino-driven stories like Batgirl & Gordita Chronicles.

That‚Äôs what Latino exclusion looks like.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
@USGAO This trend has worsened because of consolidation in the media industry.

Last year, as corporate executives lobbied regulators to approve a $43 billion merger between Discovery and WarnerMedia, I warned the @TheJusticeDept that it would eliminate opportunities for Latino workers.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: @USGAO Latinos over-index as movie-goers, streamers & more. We disproportionately subsidize the industry‚Äôs tax breaks in places like CA & NM. But at many of America's largest media companies, there are few, if any, Latinos on the Board of Directors or in senior leadership roles.

name: Joaquin Castro
Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Last year, I released the first @USGAO report on Latino representation in American media, showing that Latinos make up 12 percent of the workforce, compared to about 18 percent of the non-media workforce.

However, this only skims the surface of Latino underrepresentation.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: Over the years, I‚Äôve met with top American media executives, and I‚Äôve come to believe that the root cause of these problems is that Latinos have not been given the opportunity to tell our stories ‚Äì or to shape the way that stories about us are told.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
These negative stereotypes become dangerous tools for unscrupulous politicians to exploit for their own gain.

In its worst iteration, this combination produces the tragedy we saw in El Paso, where a madman drove 10 hours to stop what he called the ‚ÄúHispanic invasion of Texas.‚Äù

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: It‚Äôs not just a question of which actor lands a role or which author gets published. The defining images & narratives that come out of American media affect every Latino or Latina interviewing to be an accountant, a lawyer, an engineer, or a teacher, in a room full of strangers.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: These depictions obscure the positive, real-life roles of Latinos as essential workers who got us through the early days of the pandemic, immigrant entrepreneurs giving new life to withering towns in the Midwest, and trailblazers across almost every American industry.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
For decades, the American media industry has been running extended commercials focused on the most harmful Latino stereotypes.

Latinos are portrayed as gangbangers, drug dealers, and quote-unquote illegals, and Latinas are reduced to hypersexualized tropes.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
@USCAnnenberg Latino invisibility in US media creates a void in narrative where stereotypes & bigotry can fester. In 100 of the top films from 2019, nearly 40 percent of top-billed Hispanic and Latino characters were depicted as criminals or ex-convicts. 

40 percent.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: RT @PabloReports: @MSalasBlair @JoaquinCastrotx @USGAO @RepMaloney @HispanicCaucus Report here: https://t.co/rngGD3w9e9

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
In fact, last year, researchers at @USCAnnenberg found that across 1,300 top-grossing films from 2007-2019, just 3.5 percent of lead roles went to Hispanic or Latino actors or actresses.

In more than 40 percent of these films, there were no Latino characters at all.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: The GAO report that we‚Äôre here to discuss today is an opportunity to tie all of those fields together and look at the impact of Latino exclusion across the American media industry.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Latino stories are missing from the movies we watch, the textbooks our children read, and the mastheads of the newspapers that shape how we see the world.

As a result, our fellow Americans simply don‚Äôt know who Latinos are.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: But despite our numbers and growing power, our stories have been systemically excluded from Hollywood and the American media, which are the dominant image-creating and narrative-defining institutions in our country.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Growing up on the Westside of San Antonio, I was often glued to the television. But what I saw on screen rarely matched the world around me.

Latinos make up nearly 20% of the country, and our contributions have shaped this country‚Äôs development and prosperity for centuries.

name: Joaquin Castro

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: Rep. Castro: The Bipartisan Safer Communities Act that I voted to pass this summer has money in it for mental health purposes. Mental health has been under-resourced for too long, and we need to fix that. (2/2)

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
The #InflationReductionAct makes important progress on many fronts, but capping insulin at $35/month for seniors is one of the big wins.

My grandmother struggled with diabetes, and the cost of insulin was always a burden. Nobody should struggle to afford the medicine they need. https://t.co/NFXdUsTqPo

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: RT @jess_mc: there was a field hospital in central park and we were using shipping trucks as morgues

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
The #InflationReductionAct is paid for in two important ways:

1‚É£ Reforming tax laws to make sure that big corporations and the richest Americans pay their fair share of taxes.

2‚É£ Allowing Medicare to negotiate prescription drug prices ‚Äî just like private insurers do.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Investing in our nation‚Äôs future means building the world-class public transit system that Americans deserve.

The #InflationReductionAct expands transportation options in low and middle-income communities across Texas and the country.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Extreme weather has raised utility bills for many San Antonio homeowners and renters.

The #InflationReductionAct lowers the cost of energy-efficient appliances like rooftop solar, electric HVAC and water heaters to help cut consumer energy bills.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
As our economy recovers from the pandemic, good-paying jobs in clean energy can open pathways to the middle class.

The #InflationReductionAct will bring manufacturing jobs back home while increasing production of clean tech, heat pumps, mineral processing & electric vehicles.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: Our kids deserve to grow up breathing clean air. Through the #InflationReductionAct, the federal government will invest in locally led projects to reduce pollution in underserved neighborhoods in San Antonio and across the country.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
The #InflationReductionAct also makes the biggest investments to stop climate change in American history.

This bill will cut carbon emissions by 40% by 2030 ‚Äì a huge accomplishment that will protect Americans from the increasing dangers of climate change.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Over the past few years, big pharma executives have lined their pockets by hiking prices for lifesaving drugs.

The #InflationReductionAct requires drug companies to rebate the difference back to Medicare if prices rise higher than inflation.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Seniors are the only group for whom vaccines are not already free.

Under the #InflationReductionAct, seniors will be able to get COVID-19 vaccines, shingles vaccines, and others without having to pay out-of-pocket costs.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Many of the #InflationReductionAct's biggest wins are for seniors living on fixed incomes.

This act expands federal assistance with Medicare premiums & prescription drug co-pays for those making less than $20,385/year ($27,465 for couples) saving an average of $5,000/year.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: Rising Medicare premiums have made it harder for seniors to plan their retirement. The #InflationReductionAct ensures that seniors enrolled in Medicare Part D won‚Äôt see their premiums increase by more than 6% year-over-year through 2029.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Right now, there is no cap on out-of-pocket costs for prescription drugs in Medicare, leaving some patients responsible for thousands of dollars in out-of-pocket expenses.

Under the #InflationReductionAct, Medicare out-of-pocket costs will be capped at $2,000/year.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
The #InflationReductionAct will finally allow Medicare to negotiate drug prices, keeping more money in your pocket.

Seniors earned their Medicare benefits. No one should have to shell out thousands of dollars a year for medications they need.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
The #InflationReductionAct lowers health insurance costs for 13 MILLION Americans by an average of $800 a year.

Today's vote will prevent premium hikes on ACA marketplace plans by extending federal premium subsidies. Most Americans will see premiums of $10/month or less.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: Lifesaving medications should be within reach for everyone. That‚Äôs why the #InflationReductionAct caps insulin costs at $35/month for seniors on Medicare, saving many seniors hundreds of dollars a month.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Today, I voted to pass the #InflationReductionAct to create good-paying jobs, lower health care & energy costs and cut prescription drug prices for seniors.

Here‚Äôs how this bill will cut inflation and help San Antonians save money. üëá

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: When they went off to war, our veterans fought for us. When they get home, Congress should do everything in our power to fight for them. 14/14

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: The Honoring Our PACT Act will change the lives of millions of veterans. To learn more about what this new law means, visit https://t.co/cdrQU16EuP ‚Äî and please, help us spread the word to your family, friends, and community members who served. 13/14 https://t.co/OGQaHbTRuo

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
In response, Rosie Torres and other advocates rallied in front of the Capitol, calling on the Senate to do the right thing.

After their show of strength, the Honoring Our PACT Act got the votes it needed. 12/14 https://t.co/BfpQPF7JA6

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Earlier this year, the Honoring Our PACT Act passed the House and Senate, leaving just a handful of procedural hurdles to clear before it could become law.

But at the last minute, 25 Republican senators changed their minds and voted to block the bill from moving forward. 11/14 https://t.co/seAR7OJ8zC

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
This Congress, those efforts cumulated in the Honoring Our PACT Act, which was written to help generations of veterans, including Agent Orange survivors.

The Honoring Our PACT Act was bipartisan, bicameral legislation, and veterans were counting on us to get it passed. 10/14 https://t.co/8HAllLl8cO

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
In Congress, I was part of a growing coalition of legislators who were determined to make change.

In 2018, I introduced a bill to improve tracking of burn pit-related deaths & illnesses. Over the next 4 years, I wrote and joined more than a dozen bills related to burn pits. 9/14 https://t.co/7fkXtCV8d3

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
With burn pits, I saw history repeating itself.

Decades ago, when Vietnam veterans came home with injuries caused by Agent Orange, they struggled to get the care they needed.

The government broke its promise to Vietnam veterans. This time, we had to do better. 8/14

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
One of the veterans I met was William Garza Jr., a brave Marine who enlisted after graduating from Los Fresnos High School in South Texas.

By the time I met him, William had cancer caused by his exposure to burn pits. He died at 38. 7/14 https://t.co/plCrPSeAqC

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
After our meeting, I organized forums across Texas to hear from veterans about the impact of burn pits on their health.

These men and women put their lives on the line for our country. But when they got sick, the VA wasn't prepared to care for them. 6/14 https://t.co/zkvdem6gNE

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
As Le Roy shared his story, I was shocked by how little the VA was doing to help veterans like him. 

We have a sacred obligation to our veterans. The federal government shouldn‚Äôt make them jump through hoops just to get basic care. 5/14

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Le Roy Torres, a member of the Army Reserves, deployed to Iraq in 2007. 

He came home with crushing headaches, dizziness, and a cough he couldn‚Äôt shake. After a years-long effort to get diagnosed, he learned that burn pits were responsible for his illness. 4/14 https://t.co/w0fN5WBQqL

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
During our nation‚Äôs conflicts in the Middle East, the military used open-air burn pits to dispose of everything from munitions to medical waste.

These pits burned 24 hours a day, seven days a week, filling the air with toxic smoke. 3/14 https://t.co/TGhoOusLIK

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: My work to help burn pit survivors began more than five years ago, when retired Army Captain @trooper1999 and his wife @ROSIETO59994621 visited my office in San Antonio to talk about the long-term consequences of burn pit exposure. 2/14 https://t.co/LSb7pHUExF

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
The enactment of the Honoring Our PACT Act represents the largest expansion of veterans‚Äô health care and benefits in decades.

As we celebrate this historic law, I want to share part of the story behind how we got it done ‚Äî and highlight the heroes who made it possible. 1/14 https://t.co/FIS5TeBISV

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: So it‚Äôs not just a matter of which actor/actress lands a role. The defining images and narratives that come out of Hollywood affect every Latina interviewing to be an accountant, lawyer, engineer, etc, in a room of strangers who see her as Hollywood has defined her community. 11/

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: And portrayal (by American media which is the most powerful narrative-creating, image-defining institution in the world) ‚Äî as Narco or Batgirl ‚Äî profoundly affects how we see ourselves and how the country and the world see us. That‚Äôs what‚Äôs at stake here. 10/

name: Joaquin Castro

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: Here‚Äôs where Hollywood comes in. That void in narrative has been filled historically by damaging stereotypes generated by American media from hard news to Hollywood. Latinos as lazy, as greasers, as criminals, as illegal, etc. That‚Äôs the ugly part of Hollywood‚Äôs legacy. 4/

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: Ask yourself - when you were in school, how many Latino historical figures, if any, did you learn about? Unless you‚Äôre from a handful of states the answer is probably zero despite the fact that almost 1 in 5 Americans is Latino. 3/

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: Our history is barely, sometimes only recently, covered in American or state history textbooks. Most Americans couldn‚Äôt name 3 Latinos who‚Äôve made an important or significant contribution to America because they were never taught that any of us did anything worth a damn. 2/

name: Joaquin Castro

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
We need a broadening of the mind about who can succeed in publishing and every field.

Today's conversation should be a step forward in our efforts to do that. @PenguinRandom can use their leverage to change the industry, and Latino consumers will reward them if they do.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Brilliant Latino authors, publishers, and media executives aren‚Äôt hard to find.

But for Latinos to succeed in publishing, executives need to put aside their antiquated ideas of what a star author or publisher looks like.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Last year, I released a report from the GAO showing that while Latinos make up nearly 20 percent of the U.S. workforce, we make up less than 10 percent of the publishing industry.

That‚Äôs unacceptable ‚Äì and we need a real commitment and plan from publishing houses to do better.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
There is real concern that the Penguin merger could also hurt opportunities for Latino authors and publishers.

Mergers disproportionately lead to layoffs for women and minorities, who have a harder time getting in the door in the first place.
https://t.co/8xSqEHLwVD

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
For generations, Latinos have been reduced to stereotypes or ignored entirely by the media ‚Äì and it‚Äôs partly why most Americans don‚Äôt know who Latinos are.

In that void, hatred and xenophobia multiply, with very real consequences for Latinos and for the country.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
During today‚Äôs meeting, Latino authors raised concerns about lower marketing budgets for their books and lackluster recruitment of Latino authors.

When publishing houses try to advertise Latino stories without Latino voices, their efforts can be tone-deaf or actively harmful.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text:
Even without this merger, Latino authors are already being overlooked. Two years ago, the @nytimes published a study showing that 95 percent of the major English-language fiction books published between 1950-2018 were written by white authors.

https://t.co/aG2lfzs8Ur

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: Right now, @PenguinRandom is attempting to merge with @SimonSchuster. If the merger goes through, Penguin will dominate nearly half of the publishing market, giving it incredible leverage over which books are bought and how much authors are paid.

name: Joaquin Castro
tweet_text: This afternoon, I convened a meeting with executives from @PenguinRandom to hear from Latino authors, agents, and publishers about the serious ramifications of excluding Latinos from the publishing industry. üßµ
